alert.note: Alert for Central Highlands; Chaves County Plains; Chuska Mountains; Curry County; De Baca County; East Slopes Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Eastern Lincoln County; Eastern San Miguel County; Espanola Valley; Estancia Valley; Far Northeast Highlands; Far Northwest Highlands; Glorieta Mesa Including Glorieta Pass; Guadalupe County; Harding County; Jemez Mountains; Johnson and Bartlett Mesas Including Raton Pass; Lower Rio Grande Valley; Middle Rio Grande Valley, Albuquerque Metro Area; Northeast Highlands; Northern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Northwest Highlands; Northwest Plateau; Quay County; Roosevelt County; San Agustin Plains and Adjacent Lowlands; San Francisco River Valley; Sandia, Manzano Mountains Including Edgewood; Santa Fe Metro Area; South Central Highlands; South Central Mountains; Southern Sangre de Cristo Mountains; Southwest Chaves County; Southwest Mountains; Tusas Mountains Including Chama; Union County; Upper Rio Grande Valley; Upper Tularosa Valley; West Central Highlands; West Central Mountains; West Central Plateau (New Mexico) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.senderName: NWS Albuquerque (Northern and Central New Mexico)
info.headline: Special Weather Statement issued March 18 at 2:24PM MDT by NWS Albuquerque
info.description: ...MOUNTAIN SNOW TO RESUME BY MONDAY AND PERSIST THROUGH MIDWEEK... ...STRONG WINDS POSSIBLE OVER PORTIONS OF EASTERN NEW MEXICO EARLY TO MID NEXT WEEK... A relatively warm and moist southwest to westerly flow at mountain top levels into western and central New Mexico will resume late Sunday night and persist through at least Wednesday before tapering off. Significant accumulations of heavy wet snow are possible for the northern and western mountains above elevations of 7500 feet during this time. Resulting impacts may include difficult travel over mountain passes, especially into southern Colorado. Substantial accumulations of heavy wet snow may also break tree limbs which could lead to power outages as well as collapse inadequately supported structures such as carports. Lower elevations of western and central New Mexico will see fluctuating snow levels with daytime rain and snow and nighttime snow, making snow accumulation forecasts challenging. Eastern New Mexico will see strong southwest winds gusting to around 50 to 55 mph, especially Tuesday and Wednesday, when near to above normal temperatures combine to create potential for elevated critical fire weather conditions mainly along and east of the Pecos Valley. Residents and travelers through northern and western New Mexico should remain cautiously aware of deteriorating weather conditions starting late Sunday night. Stay updated on the forecast at weather.gov/abq or through your preferred media outlet, and consider alternate travel plans if necessary.
